DIV1.P: INDIGENCE, AND NOBLENESS OF MIND. A COMEDY IN FIVE ACTS, From the German of KOTZEBUE.
NEW-YORK: PRINTED FOR CHARLES SMITH AND S. STEPHENS. 1800.

LIST.ITEM: ADELBERT, a Polander lodging in Van Snarl's House.
HANS WILLIAM, a young Dutchman, a suitor to Van Snarl's daughter.
LOUISA, supposed daughter of Mrs. Rose, house-keeper to Van Snarl.
MRS. ROSE, house-keeper to Von Snarl.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I. SCENE I. A Parlour: at the back are Doors with glass Pannels, through which is discovered a large Compting-House, where several clerks are writing.
DIV2.STAGE: NICOLAS laying the breakfast on the table.
DIV2.P: HOW plaguy cross my master is before breakfast! not a good word comes from his mouth till he has put a roll down his throat— (piles up rolls on a plate)—It is no lit∣tle matter that brings him into temper. He will make as much havoc among these rolls, as a stage coach would with six insides. Oh, here he comes—now I shall get my trimmings, because I asked for a bit of lace to my coat. "My master opens his eyes and his mouth at the same moment in a morning, and between hunger and ill temper, snaps at every thing he sees."

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: And so you must have lace to your coat! you impertinent puppy! to give me your opinions!

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: I did not mean any thing, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: And what do you speak for, if you don't mean any thing? hold your tongue at once—that's the shortest way of saying nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: I did not look on it as how you would be angry.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn
SP.P:
Who says I'm angry?—Rascal, if you did not know the sweetness of my temper, you would not dare to open your lips: always trying to vex me and spoil my temper! But I will be quite happy and easy, I'm deter∣mined,
in spite of you all. I'll be placid—I'll be serene, —I'll be meek—I'll be— (turns to the table and speaks in a passion)—plague on you—what do you bring me this heap of dry rolls for? Fetch a muffin.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Yes sir (aside) I wish he would begin to eat—no∣thing cures his ill humor like plenty of rolls and muffins.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: (pours out tea) If a man can lay up an hundred thousand pounds, and not have a right to his own way of thinking at least, there's an end to every thing at once. If I had not the sweetest temper in the world (Nicholas re∣turns with several muffins)—Where's the muffins—Pup∣py! you don't think my liveries handsome enough!— D'ye call these muffins? Butter a roll or two. Don't let me see you open your (begins eating muffins) mouth again, sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: (aside) I don't dare answer till he has swallowed.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: (having swallowed his morsel) Do you starve?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: (observing that he had eat) No, we know better how to follow our master's example. We be main well as to the inside lining. "But—lud! Sir—there's our neighbor's servants be as fine as so many puppets at the wax work.

SP.SPEAKER: "V. Sn.
SP.P: Yes, and live on the same diet as puppets at the wax work. Go down into the kitchen, you rascal, and stop your mouth."

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: What answer be I to give the Polandish gentle∣man, that lodges up stairs?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: What! now you want to plague me again!

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: He have been waiting this half hour to know if you be at leisure.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, I cannot hurry my breakfast for him— Zounds! you don't let me swallow my victuals. What is the use of money if one cannot be happy at one's meals? (Nicolas going) What are you (peevishly) going away for, before I have done speaking? Probably Mr. Adel∣bert wants to pay his rent—so, as soon as I've eat this roll tell him I'm at leisure. Go—and don't open your lips.—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: (taking a large bit of muffin) Laced liveries!— no, no—solid comfort for me. Oh, here's my lodger.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter ADELBERT, in a Polish dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Mr. Van Snarl, I come to wait on you—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Rent in hand—strict to your word, eh? I'm glad to see it. It's not always the case with gentlemen of small fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: With gentlemen of every fortune —They profess an obligation over which wealth has no influence.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Aye! what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: I should not like my rent in that coin: Honour makes a good cabinet medal, but won't pass on 'Change.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: In my country, in Poland, it will—I have seen it too in England, at the call of friendship or humani∣ty, accepted and endorsed for a man's whole estate.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Psha! why d'ye plague me about England?— People love to praise every country but the country they live in.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I'm afraid I disturb you.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: No, no, sit down; a punctual tenant is never any disturbance. Only that rascal Nicolas has been trying to spoil the sweetness of my temper. Puppy! wants a live∣ry with a bit af lace (imitates Nicolas) as if he could eat lace! (forced laugh) ha—ha—as if he could eat lace, eh, Mr. Adelbert! Now you're a sensible man—you prefer the plain dress of your country—you're economical.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Necessity imposes that duty on me.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Aye, aye, I know you're not so rich as I am. I have been laying up money these twenty years. You'd, hardly believe, Mr. Adelbert, how interest upon interest, once set a rolling, gathers like a snowball. And you see (points to the compting house) there they are at it—there's my mill going, eh! look—there it goes.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: You are a happy man, Mr. Von Snarl.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Happy! to be sure I am. Why should not we all be happy? Come, now to business.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (sits down) Well then, I owe, Sir, already a debt to you; I come to ask your permission to encrease it.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Eh!

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: It is with the utmost reluctance I venture on this freedom;—but you would greatly oblige me by honoring my draft for twenty pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: (staring at him) What!

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: If from riches you derive happiness, you have assuredly learnt their real value, that of imparting happi∣ness to others; and I am confident you will not turn your back on one, who entrusts you with his distress.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: (turns away from Adelbert) Thank'ye for the compliment.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: My little revenue is secure, but my remittances are not arrived. If in the mean time—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, I hope they'll arrive soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Were I not satisfied on that head I would not—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Shall I pour you out a dish of tea?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: You will indulge me then?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: You have seen the papers I suppose—no news—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (piqued) Mr. Von Snarl, you are a rich man, and accustomed to speculations.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Speculations! well what of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Did you ever speculate on the face of an honest man?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Did I ever see one? (sarcastically.)

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: It is true I can give little security. This minia∣ture, (drawing a miniature from his bosom) is the only one I am able to offer. It is set with a few brilliants, of no great value, and I am sorry to part with it. But if you would accept it as a pledge—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: A pledge!—why the devil! d'ye take me for a pawnbroker?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I beg pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: What I give, I give without pledge, bond or note.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Even to a stranger?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Stranger or no stranger, we are bound to assist distress without interest.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Generous!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: D'ye observe?—when we can—but my purse won't bear a loan at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Only twenty pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P:
Twenty pounds! twenty devils. I had yester∣day two bankruptcies in my books—one of my ships from Africa lost, with a cargo of 400 blacks on board—besides the parson's widow, Mrs. Rose and her daughter, whom I
maintain, as you know, in the house. I won't say what they cost me, because that's charity—but I know I have a tender heart and a sweet temper, that would be my ruin, if I did not watch my purse at both ends. But come—if I can't lend you my money, I'll give you my advice. Go to Levi, the great Jew, and he'll lend you, on the picture nearly its full value.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: To a Jew!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: A Jew! well, what of that? I would as soon do business with a Jew as a Christian. He'll deal with you as a man and a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: And not as you have done. I beg pardon for the trouble of this visit. (going)

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Hark'ye, Mr. Adelbert, (Adelbert returns) I ex∣pect to see my son in law every hour, and I shall want a room for him. I don't mean to be uncivil to you, because you have not got twenty pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I understand you—I shall provide myself with another lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, well, as you like for that: I don't mean to turn you out of the house. You'll dine with me before you go away to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Dine with you! you do me too much honor.— (contemptuously)

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Nay, I insist on it. You must take leave of the girls this afternoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: That's true. I owe the young ladies every atten∣tion. I shall wait on you. Exit Adelbert.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Now that's what I call plaguy dry. Owes the young ladies!—He does'nt owe the young ladies half so much as he owes me. And then he'd borrow!—an inso∣lent rascal!—borrow!—Talk to me as he would to a pawn-broker!—If I had'nt the sweetest temper in the world—Nicolas!
Ask Totum, if there are letters by the mail to-day, and tell Mrs. Homily to come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Mrs, Rose, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Mrs. Rose, sirrah! yes Mrs. Rose.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Yes, Sir. Exit Nicolas.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: May not I call her Mrs. Homily if I choose it? Plague on it, I must not have my jokes now in my own house.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Mr. Totum says he will bring you the letters him∣self, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: In how many hours, minutes, and seconds, has he calculated he shall come?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: He said he would come presently, Sir,—Mrs. Rose is here, Sir. Exit Nicolàs.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, Mrs. Homily, whither in such a hurry?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Oh, lud, Sir, here is every thing wanted at the same instant. In the compting house they want their cof∣fee—The cook wants rice and currants—the footman wants his breakfast, and Miss Josephine wants honey water for her hair.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, and I want to speak to you. I expect company to dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Company! no I hope not.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: I have two Burgomasters to dine with me, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Oh, Gemini, I must go to to the larder di∣rectly. The kitchen is not prepared for two Burgomas∣ters.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: (pettishly) What's the kitchen to me, provided there be plenty on the table? Next, I suppose, I must not have Burgomasters to dine with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Pretty talking! it would be a fine thing in∣deed, if one could blow good things on the table, forsooth, as they do in the Rambling Night's Entertainments.— That's all sinful witchcraft, and I am sure you cannot expect a clergyman,s widow, as I am, to meddle with any such devilish practices.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: No: but I expect my house-keeper to provide me a good dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Well, well—I'll go to the larder and see what there is for you. Yonder's Mr. Totum with your letters. By the time you have read them I shall know more about it. Exit Mrs. Rose.
Three bales of goods to Van Cormack and Co—Right.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Totum!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (without) Ready, Mr. Van Snarl—Item; numero four—cargo of Spanish wares—right—post Don Candi∣morez—right—place four hundred marks to account of Louis Vancaper and Co—right—call in—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Totum!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (without) Ready, Mr. Van Snarl—call in bills on Carpo and Co. No time to note.
Mr. Van Snarl, your very obedient servant.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, Totum, is the mail arrived?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Received letters—read—speak contents, names, signatures—say if right—no time to note— (gives a parcel of letters to Van Snarl) Imprimis—a letter bearing royal signet—parcel annexed— (goes to the door of the compt∣ing house) Clever door! convenient—hear clerks with left ear—letters with right—credit time (places himself in the midway of the door sometimes watching the clerks within, and sometimes attending to Van Snarl)

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: (opening the parcel) How long has the mail been arrived?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (looking hastily at a clock, which is seen within) Thirteen minutes, nine seconds, and a fraction.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Eh! the deuce! a letter from our Prime Min∣ister! (reads) "Greeting—Whereas it appears from the report of our Secretary for the Naval Department, that you have procured an expeditious delivery of the articles required of you; We, therefore, to testify our good will towards you, send you the inclosed snuff-box—Your affec∣tionate friend, Richtenstein."

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (advances) Congratulate—this is a day—this is an hour—day fourteen—month April—hour ten in forenoon —fifty three minutes, seven seconds, and a fraction. Ha! (looks at the box which Van Snarl holds in his hand)— brilliants—I underwrite

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Doubtless—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P:
Worth more or less, twelve hundred and ninety-nine
dollars, three guldens, eighteen stivers, one groot, and three pfennings.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: I'll value it at two thousand dollars.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Right—secondly, a letter from correspondent at Amsterdam (gives a second letter and goes again to his post at the door of the compting house)

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Vander Housen! (opens the letter and reads) "Sir, this is to inform you, that, under date of seventeenth ultimo, we have sent to your direction a son, viz. Hans William—hope you will safely receive the same, and beg you will consign him forthwith to your daughter."

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Not arrived as per advice—hope they book'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: (reads) "Tho' young folks are of late much fal∣len in value, we can assure you, said Hans William is of extra good quality, and will, we dare say, give satisfac∣tion. Remain, errors excepted, Sir, your most faithful servant and friend to command, Vander Housen & Co."

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Congratulate—ha, ha! you'll have a wedding— you must give a ball—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: I will give a dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: A fire-work in your garden.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Your own figure all in a blaze.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Eh!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Like a flying mercury (imitates the attitude of a mercury) with a snuff-box in your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Zounds! d'ye consider what all this will cost?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Total, seventeen dollars, eight guldens, nine sti∣vers, three pfennings and a fraction—ha! Oh, it will cut a dash! we'll go halves.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Halves! Totum! Why, Totum, you're out of your senses, Totum.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: One expence to serve for two weddings.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Two weddings! who is the other bridegroom? (TOTUM draws himself up conceitedly.) What! your∣self?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Received this morning—hour nine in the fore∣noon, forty-three minutes, seventeen seconds, a letter— note the contents—poor dear father deceased.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Your father dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P:
Died twenty-fifth instant, four in the morning, fifty-nine minutes, and three seconds, aged seventy eight
years, four months, two weeks, five days, fourteen hours, and a quarter—left to Tilman Totum, sole heir, eighty thousand marks.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Totum, take a chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Exclusive, in the hands of Van Creeper & Co. one thousand bales of Panama dowlas—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Dear Totum, pray sit down.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Six chests of silver plate (takes a chair) —twen∣ty four cargoes of Nankin muslins—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Let we wipe the cushion.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: And one hundred and eight jars of fine Smyrna oils—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Mr. Totum, I insist on your being seated.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Besides a box of uncounted livres, stivers, groots, pfennings, guilders, schellings, florins, dollars, ducats, doubloons, milreas, sequins, and duros, all brand new, never been yet in circulation.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Dearest Mr. Totum, do me the favour to sit down. [They both sit.]

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Father deceased—enter on trade—engage capital —ensure on my own risk—build ware-house—settle cor∣respondence—marry.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: And who's the bride?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Louisa Rose—a good girl.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Good! why, you're mad—she has not a farth∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: A pretty face—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: What interest will that bring?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: A pair of white hands—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Which can earn nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Hm! a pretty little foot—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Poh, poh—why, Totum, you're bewitch'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Totum, you're bewitch'd—right. The devil draws on my heart—must accept—flesh weak—temptation strong—pretty girl, an enchanting angel—solitary batche∣lor, a poor devil—so, if you have no objection—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: None in the world, dear Totum. (aside) I shall get rid of a boarder, whom I took into my house to please my daughter. But have you spoke to the girl?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Occasionally—time suiting.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: How does she seem to like you?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Little rogue! loves me—secretly.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Secretly!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Prove it—pro primo—whenever she sees me, laughs—shews she's pleased: Pro secundo, when she hears me coming, runs away—shews she is bashful: Pro tertio, when I speak to her, answers at random—shews her mind is so engaged, she does not know what she says: Pro quarto, always jokes about my wig.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: That shews plainly she is in love.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Only one little article makes me uneasy. That Polander up stairs—I perceive certain looks—here, there —from, to—seem to mean something.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: I can make you easy on that head, for he shall not stay in my house. Between you and me, Mr. To∣tum, I suspect the Pole to be a spy.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Hm! why not?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: I see he is very poor—and who can tell? It would not be amiss if you could take an opportunity, when he is gone out, of just—eh? in his room, eh?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Examine his papers, boxes, and so forth—I un∣derstand you—Just what I wish'd—Shall find if there is any thing going on between him and Louisa—I'll be on the watch—At what hour do we dine to-day? Answer —three o'clock—Burgomasters never wait—Your hum∣ble servant to command, Tilman Totum—sole heir to eighty thousand marks, six chests of silver plate, one hun∣dred and eight jars of Smyrna oil, &c. &c. &c.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: This will be a rare riddance for me—Where is that giddy baggage my daughter all this while? Oh, here she comes with Louisa. Come hither, Josephine.
I have something to tell you—can you guess what it is?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: No, but I am dying with curiosity to know it.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Ah, you're a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Yes, unfortunately.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: And you, (to LOUISA) I suppose, are dying too—you are a woman too, eh, Louisa?

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, there's a grand dinner to-day, and the grand dinner has its grand reasons.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Must we put on our best gowns?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: If you like.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: That is according as the reasons are worth them.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Suppose it's a bridegroom—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: (laughs) Oh, la! have you ordered one for me, papa?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Suppose I have—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: What! from China?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Psha! he comes from one of the first houses in Amsterdam.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: (with affected gravity) Does he cost much?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: That's very dear.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: And your heart into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: That's too much.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: It's little enough for a good husband, so don't plague me with any more questions.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Yes, there's one more I must ask. What is his name?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Hans William.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh—then I won't have him.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I have no objection to William,—but Hans—po∣sitively Hans must not come near me.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: There, there! that's the way—no matter how deserving a man be—if his name do not happen to strike your fancy, he is to be laugh'd at. Take pattern by Lou∣isa—she is a good girl, and knows how to behave herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: Josephine is only joking, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Joking! zounds! every body is to make jokes but myself. I have found a husband too for Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: From Holland too?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: No—home manufacture.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: And his name not Hans?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, and think of making up your wedding suit.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh—there will be time enough for that.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Suppose your bridegroom should come to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Suppose some accidents should happen to-mor∣row?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: What accidents; pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P:
Suppose he should not like me, and suppose we
should quarrel, and suppose I should scratch his eyes out before the wedding?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Why, then you'll have the comfort of marrying a blind man; for, to tell you plainly, the affair is conclu∣ded, and if you don't take him, and like him too when he is come, never expect to have a farthing of my money; and another time you may provide for yourself. (angrily.) If I had not the sweetest temper in the world, these silly girls would contrive to put me in a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: But, Louisa, we forgot to enquire the name of your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Oh, Dear! that was not said in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: It will prove as much in earnest, I fancy, as mine. Do you think I'll let my father send me to Holland, like a ton of flax?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Ah, Josephine! you are very happy;—for you have a father—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Will you change fathers with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: No—not for all the world. My father, to be sure, won't see me; and I always thought that very strange: But, in every thing else, he is so good to me, and so kind!—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: But not very wise▪ I think. He refuses to see you, and does not know that he sees you every hour. Un∣der the name of Mrs. Rose's daughter you have won his affection, in spite of his prejudice and absurdities.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: If I was but sure of that, Josephine!

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I am sure of it—and, what is better, he loves you for your own sake: the parent's vanity has no hand in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Why should he shun me so, Josephine? An't I his child? And, indeed, indeed, I never did any thing willingly to offend him. Why should he drive me from his sight, as soon as I was born? I grew up far away from him, and he forbids me now to come to him, that I may take his hand, and press it to my lips.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: To be sure it is droll enough. Father and daugh∣ter live in the same house, converse together, correspond together, and yet are strangers, except by letters, which are sometimes a week in travelling from one to the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P:
Yesterday he got my last letter. When I sat down to it, Josephine, my heart was quite full:—and I
beg'd so hard to see him; and the words were, all, so blotted, he must have seen that I cried all the while I was writing it. I fancied in the evening he looked more thoughtful than ever. Perhaps he may be brought to give his consent to see me at last. Don't you think he might, Josephine?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: If I were to tell you that I saw him wipe a tear away with his hand—

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Did you, indeed? I wish I had seen it! But it would not have signified. Ah, Josephine! 'tis very hard when a child is not allowed to kiss off a tear from the cheek of her father.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. ROSE, with a letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Well, child, here is a letter for you again— (LOUISA snatches the letter hastily from her, and pres∣ses it to her lips.).

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Would not one think it was from her sweetheart? Well, I'll leave you to your transports;—when they are over, I shall expect you; and in the mean time I'll settle the colour of our wedding suits. Exit JOSEPHINE.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: (reads) "My dear and only daughter (she kis∣ses the letter again) your last letter has drawn tears from my eyes. Your wish to see me is mine also." Oh! then I shall be so happy! "Yet, as you value my life▪ do not insist on your request. I have withheld myself eighteen years from your sight—I dare not yet meet it—never a∣gain enquire the reason. (weeps—then after a pause reads,) You must have occasion for money—yet you ask for none—I therefore inclose you a note—you must want for nothihg—all I have is yours—I received it all from your mother—Resemble her! Adieu, my dear, dear child! Love your father, who has no other joy in this world than you!"—Then he never will see me! what have I done to deserve this! (weeps.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Dear child, trust to Providence! We must none of us despair—things may change for the better in a moment. Oh! if you had heard my husband's discourse about poverty and want! Poor dear Dr. Orius!

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Poverty! Oh, that's a word the heart knows no∣thing about.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Because the heart knows nothing about hun∣ger and thirst. Want is a very bad companion; and you may thank your father for never letting you know it. See how much the note is for, that he has sent you.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: It's for much more than I want.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Well, well, if you don't want it to-day, you may to-morrow—but I warrant you'll give it away before to-morrow, to some poor person or other: [LOUISA appears suddenly thoughtful.] Well—what will you do with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Oh, I must not tell you. What I intend to do would be of no value if it were told.— (Looks at the note) three hundred crowns! I wish they were three thousand, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Oh, you extravagant child! three hundred crowns! you won't surely give that sum away!

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: No—I'll lay it out at interest—I'll be an usurer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: An usurer, forsooth! Ah, child, child! you learn to cypher and cast accounts, to be sure; but how many pence there are in a dollar, you'll never learn to reckon as long as you live. Exit Mrs. ROSE.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: That, now, may be very true: and, somehow or other, I always thought charity much easier than arithme∣tick. I know Mr. Van Snarl takes a deal of pleasure in counting up his dollars; but, for my part, I think there is more pleasure, by half, in giving money to the distress'd, and letting them count it for me. Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II. An Apartment in VAN SNARL'S House.

SP.SPEAKER: Van Snarl.
SP.P: NAY, brother, its very strange you won't let me tell you the news.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I have no relish for news—Few old things of the world are worth much, and the new ones are worth less.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: There, now you are out of temper—It's a strange thing a man cannot be always easy and happy as I am. I will tell you for all that; Louisa Rose is going to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Louisa Rose!—to whom?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Guess.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I cannot rack my brain with conjecture.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: To my book-keeper, Tilman Totum.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: (appears surprised) I am sorry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: His father has just left him eighty thousand marks.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I am heartily sorry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Why, that's droll. I think it's a devilish neat thing—He means to set up in trade for himself, and he thinks Louisa will make him a very suitable wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Fie, fie!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Brother Leopold, you are a queer fellow:— why should she not?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: A girl like an angel, and a fellow like a monkey.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Yes—but the angel is as poor as the devil, and the monkey is as rich as a jew.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: She may starve with Totum, in spite of his riches.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: (with a sneer). Nay, how can that happen.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: If the fool does not know that money is not wealth.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Money not wealth?—What nonsense you talk! —Pray what is wealth then?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: The free and liberal use we make of it. Wealth, brother, is like a sword, placed in various hands. Fools are laughed at for their ignorance in using it; knaves, who grasp it, hurt their neighbours with it; wise and be∣nevolent men, alone, know how to guard themselves with it, while they protect the weak, who want their assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, if Louisa starves, it shall not be my fault.—I'll set her off well at least—I'll give her a grand wedding dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I hope you mean to give her a portion likewise.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: A portion! d'ye think I am gone out of my senses?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: With all your money!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: That all would have been little enough by this time, if I were as romantic as you are, brother—If you are so fond of the girl, why don't you give her a portion out of your own fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: It belongs to my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Ah—if you had taken as good care of your pa∣trimony, and attended to the golden rule of multiplication, as I have done.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I have attended but to one golden rule through life, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: What may that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Humanity.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Lucky, if you had mix'd a little prudence with it; then you wou'd have been always easy and happy, as I am; that is, if you were as sweet temper'd as I am.— But you—had not you happen'd to meet with a wife—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: (interrupting him.) Let me beseech you, bro∣ther, no mention of that subject!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: I was only going to say that her fortune help'd you up.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Oh, Emilia!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Aye, aye, she was a woman of the right sort— She had plenty of jewels and cash. I wish she was alive again.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, brother!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: I am only saying that if your wife was still alive—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Nay, then, you compel me to leave you. (Exit hastily.)

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: There he goes again. Was ever any man so uncivilly treated in his own house as I am! a silly fellow, making such a perpetual wimpering for the loss of one wife!—I have buried three, one after the other, without breaking my heart. That's the difference between Leo∣pold and me—he carries his remembranee of his wife a∣bout in his mind, and I carry mine in my pockets.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. Another Apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Let me go, Mr. Totum—I have no time for talking—My master has two Burgomasters to dine with him—and, thank heaven! there's plenty for them!—A sirloin of beef, roast fillet of veal, scollop'd oysters, col∣lar'd eel, anchovies, and a furmenty pudding.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: No time for talking! forty-seven words, four ar∣ticles, and five stops. Listen! do you know, Mrs. Rose, —sweet Mrs. Rose,—that to-day is a day—a day—a—I cannot tell you what a day it is—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Well, and if it be a day, I warrant I can pro∣vide for it—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Brief reply—credit words.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: I always add a dish for every fresh guest, and for every bit of good news.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Good news—right. Attend, note contents—Im∣primis, Mr. Van Snarl has received a snuff-box from the Minister—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: What—the Minister of the Parish?—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Poh! psha! No, no, Prime Minister—Head-Clerk to the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: From his Majesty's Minister! Oh! then I must provide a dish of Plaice.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: In secundo, Miss Josephine's bridegroom is on the road.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: The bridegroom! I must have pigeons and a cake.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: And, thirdly—Mrs. Rose—sweet Mrs. Rose— you may take into account a second wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: A second wedding?—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Yes, note a ditto.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Oh, then I must order a goose for the second coarse—mercy on me!—there will be hardly time.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Dine at three—time in hand five hours twenty-seven minutes—no fear of deficit.—Enter items—provide plaice, pluck pigeons, gut goose, one hour, fifteen mi∣nutes—dress, stew, and roast ditto, two hours, one half quarter, and three seconds.—Balance, two hours, four minutes, twenty seven seconds, and a fraction—post credit side—therefore listen, Mrs. Rose—sweet Mrs. Rose, listen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: I tell you, Mr. Totum, since there is to be a second wedding—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: The second wedding, Mrs. Rose, depends on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: The second course does, Mr. Totum; so I'll give another look into the larder— (going.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Listen, Mrs. Rose, sweet Mrs. Rose, listen—I have placed a large sum in your hands—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: In mine!—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: The sum of my happiness—I must disclose to you the state of my books—my father being deceased—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Poor man!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Died fourteenth of last month, at fifty-nine mi∣nutes, three seconds, after four in the morning—aged se∣venty eight years, four months, two weeks, three days, fourteen hours, twelve minutes, and a quarter, ha!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Bating the odd hours, minutes, and quarter, just the very age of my late husband, poor dear Dr. Olea∣rius.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Left Tilman Totum, sole heir, eighty thousand marks.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Indeed! I am truly happy to hear it—Now I've just thought that we have got in the larder—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Psha! close the larder, open your ears and listen —I say, Mrs. Rose—sweet Mrs. Rose, listen.—Having now stock in trade, I mean to open an account of matri∣mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: (bridling and smiling.) Matrimony?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Yes—open a new firm, raise a new head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Was that the subject you wanted to speak on? Oh, Mr. Totum, you do me too much honour.

SP.SPEAKER: T.
SP.P: I do you no honour at all; I only want you to lis∣ten, Mrs. Rose; sweet Mrs. Rose, listen! I fear, above all things to cast up wrong; that, you know, to a man in business—say no more—hate a blot—therefore, without your consent, reckon nought.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Dear Mr. Totum—to be sure—but you know the world is rather ill-natured: there are some circum∣stances, that should be taken into consideration.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Allow deductions—state fairly, what heads?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: First—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Imprimis—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Difference of age.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Repairs payable by the owner; according to best of knowledge and belief, difference not great.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: True, when one has met with hardships, one looks older than one really is. But, dear Mr. Totum, marriage is a serious step; when I lost poor dear Dr. O∣learius—Heaven grant him rest!—I made a vow never to marry again.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Well, well, I don't care for your vow—that is an account balanced—credit by loss—but, sweet Mrs. Rose, my new head is yet a blank—suffer me—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Ah! dear Mr. Totum, we are poor people, who have many wants to be supplied.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: You allow the demand then?—note consent

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: (with affected satisfaction) Dearest Mr. To∣tum, you may command me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (adjusting himself.) Your daughter, I conclude—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: My daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Yes, Mrs. Totum, that will be—Happy, happy pair!

DIV3.STAGE: None but the rich deserve the fair.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Mistress Totum! Oh! you want to marry my daughter Louisa, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Whom else, the dickens! d'ye think I want to marry?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Oh, oh! Aye, aye! Well, that is nothing to me—you must speak to Louisa herself about that.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P:
Express. But, if I may debit my head with the
daughter, and credit by the mother's consent, that will be a pretty clear account.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: A mother! Oh! to be sure—well, I have a deal to say on that subject; but I am in haste now— Well, Mr. Totum, speak to Louisa yourself; you have my consent,, if you can gain Louisa's, (aside) which I am sure you never will.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Enough! You endorse the bill—she will answer it—therefore I remain, errors excepted, your obedient, faithful servant, shortly son-in-law, Tilman Totum, sole heir to eighty thousand marks, six chests of silver plate, one box of uncounted livres, stivers, &c. &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Dear heart! What will Mr. Leopold say to this? Well, well, as Heaven pleases: Mr. Totum is a pretty man, and a good man; he never fails at a sermon, and it is quite edifying to hear him chant.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. An Apartment in VAN SNARL'S House.
DIV3.STAGE: LOUISA sitting at her Work, ELLEN with a Guitar in her Hand, which she appears to be laying down, as taking leave of LOUISA.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Thank ye, Ellen; but did not you tell me, that Mr. Leopold heard you singing one day?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Yes, I did so.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: And desired you to sing the song again?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Yes; twice.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Then pray let me hear that song before you go. I am sure I shall like it, if he did.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: 'Tis one of our village ballads.

LG.L: When planets strike, and spells have pow'r
I heard a voice as from the tomb,
Starting I rise, and snatch my gown,
I see the gallant ship go down,—
But see my love no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Pray walk in, Mr. Adelbert; there is no one here who will not be glad to see you—is there, Louisa?

DIV3.STAGE: (LOUISA appears embarrassed, and rises from her chair.)

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (to JOSEPHINE.) Your friend's generous heart is ever ready to welcome the unfortunate,

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Make a curtsy, Louisa.—Mr. Adelbert is come to dine with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: By your father's invitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: That was very well done. You shall sit by one of us. Now, the question is, whether you mean to eat much or little, or to talk much or little.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I'll tell you. If you have a mind to eat very lit∣tle, and not to speak at all, you shall sit by Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I protest, I am at a loss to understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Dear! She doesn't know what she means herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: But indeed she does know what she means. Have not I seen him sit by you for hours together, without o∣pening his lips?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Nay, now I'm sure you are mistaken; Mr. Adel∣bert has always entertained me exceedingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh! I never doubted that.
SP.STAGE: Enter TOTUM, more sprucely dressed than before, and Mrs. ROSE.
(JOSEPHINE, LOUISA, and ADELBERT, converse in dumb shew; TOTUM appears to be whispering to Mrs. ROSE.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (in a low voice.) Have you dropt a word for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Speak to the girl yourself, I tell you, Mr. Totum.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: There's that cursed all Pole! When he is gone—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: He dines here.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Dines! choke him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Heaven forbid!

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: (advances to TOTUM.) Mr. Totum! I protest you have put on a new wig to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Yes—I've raised a new head. D'ye like it?—Put it on in haste—spirits in great fluctuation—high, low— up, down—from fifty to seventy.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Ha, ha!—Why really—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Don't laugh; a laugh sinks me. This day, Miss Josephine, is the most awful day of my life—I am going to file off bachelor's account, and begin a new head in the ledger of matrimony.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Then you are going to be married?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Going to be married—right.—Oh, my Louisa, if I may speak the wishes of the heart!—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: What, have you got a heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Only by debit—wants credit by ditto—I come to ask Miss Louisa, whether she will run the risk of partner∣ship with me in a new branch of trade?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Why, Louisa knows nothing of book-keeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: I beg you'll not interrupt me, Miss, while I am summing up my articles. Speak, Miss Louisa, without loss of time, may I flatter myself—

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: With what, Mr. Totum?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Transfer—heart and hand—hand and heart— please to accept a barter.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Why, I really begin to think you want to marry Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (aside.) Heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: What means this pretty smile on my Louisa's cheek?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Pure joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Pure joy!—right. A laugh—brief—credit words. (to LOUISA.) Note consent?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Indeed, Mr. Totum, you are very good; but I am not my own mistress, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Oh! I have got your mother's consent posted al∣ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Yes—but my mother knows, that—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: (maliciously to Adelbert) She is already promis∣ed. (Adelbert appears alarmed).

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Indeed, Mr. Totum, I can never be your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Never! Error in addition. Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Hold, Sir! Girls must never be asked why.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Account stands open. (looking askance at Adel∣bert). To be sure I am not the youngest in the room, but neither am I the poorest—I fancy eighty thousand marks. —Oh! here comes Mr. Leopold; he will sum up better for me— Enter LEOPOLD. Your servant, Sir; please to check account between these ladies and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: What is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: The matter, Sir, is that—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Mr. Totum wishes to marry—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Hush, Miss, do not interrupt me, while I am drawing up my articles. The matter, Sir, is that, where∣as—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: What, is it a bankruptcy in the gazette?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Whereas, Sir, it has pleased Providence to close my father's account, and to make me sole heir to eighty thousand marks, I intend instantly, and without loss of time, to open account per matrimony—to take a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Right.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: His choice is fixed on Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Right.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: But Miss Louisa—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Won't have him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Don't interrupt my articles, Miss Josephine. Miss Louisa, Sir, draws ballance by refusal—won't strike a barter—but rather chooses to strike me clear out of her books.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Very right.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Right! no, I say she is wrong; her mother's con∣sent stands to credit— (Leopold starts and is affected)— Mrs. Rose here—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: To be sure. Fortune leads to comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: (recollecting himself) Very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: But love, not fortune should lead to the altar.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Very true, likewise,

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: So we are all in the right then?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: All.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: And I get no wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Take me.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Come, come along, girls: come, gentlemen, the dinner is going in. Come, Mr. Totum, you must dine with us to-day. Totum and I are partners to-day in good fortune. Here, girls, I have not shewn you the handsome snuff-box I have received from the Minister. Look at it, brother: Totum says it is worth two thousand dollars. (gives the box to Leopold, who looks at it with indifference.)

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I wish you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Dear uncle, let me look at it. (Leopold gives the box to Josephine, by whom it is handed to others, till it comes round again to Van Snarl, who during the ensu∣ing dialogue, puts it in his pocket without attending to it.)

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Totum! why, how now? You look as sad as if your father was come to life again.—What's the mat∣ter with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Cannot you guess, Papa?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: What, has Louisa refused him? (Totum shrugs his shoulders). I supposed as much. Methinks a girl that has nothing but a smooth face to recommend her. and her feet under a strange table, might give herself fewer airs. If I had not the sweetest temper in the world—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: You would on such an occasion remind her of her dependence on you. Fie, brother, for shame!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: What, Louisa behaves like a fool, and I am to be ashamed! Mr. Totum, I'd have you know, brother, with eighty thousand marks in his bureau, has only to hold out his hand, and on every finger hangs a bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Aye, such brides, Papa, as deserve hanging.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, a good dinner will put a silly girl out of his head. Come along, children; where is my snuff-box?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I gave it to Josephine.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: And I handed it round to the company.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: And I.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel. and Tot.
SP.P: And I.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: But no one handed it to me again. (feels in his pockets).

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: No matter now: Mrs. Rose I see is growing im∣patient. The box will be found again, I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: It must be found again.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Well, after dinner. Come, your guests are waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: And the soup will be stone cold.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Soup be d—d! If all the soup in the town should freeze, I won't stir, I tell you. I have never had my box again; here—here are my pockets; here is no∣thing, and here is nothing. (turns out both his pockets.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Here are mine, to command. (turns his pockets out; they contain only a letter, which he opens and reads)
"Sir, this brings advice that your father departed this life yesterday, the twenty-fifth instant, at four A. M. fifty nine minutes, three seconds, &c. &c.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: (turns to ADELBERT) Now, Sir, it's your turn.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (appearing disturbed at the proposal) Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: I suppose, you'll consent to what all the compa∣ny must agree upon—only for form's sake, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Stand off! You cannot be in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Joke or earnest, as you like. Gentlemen do not carry smuggled goods, I suppose, in their pockets.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (nettled) If that is meant as a joke, Sir, it is, without under-rating it, a very clumsy one; but, if you are in earnest, I must inform you, that both my birth and character place me so far beyond this low suspicion, that I will sooner die than consent to give you the gross proof you require of your absurdity. I utterly despise the meanness of your conduct; and leave you, lest, by per∣sisting in it, you should rouse me to convert the contempt I feel for you, into chastisement. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: The devil!—we must not let him go— (following him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Hold! do you know what it is to charge a gen∣tleman thus, brother?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: What do I care for a gentleman, when he hops off with my snuff-box?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: (with warmth) He has not got it—it is impos∣sible—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: (observing LOUISA) Ha! Louisa the defender of Adelbert!

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Mr. Adelbert, I am sure, knows nothing of it. You may see that plain enough in his face.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: His face! why, zouuds! you don't expect to see the snuff-box in his forehead, do you? What do you say, Totum?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Set down circumstances—cast up fairly—sum to∣tal—the Pole must have the box—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Aye, that he has—but come—let us go to din∣ner—he is not out of the town.—Plague on him, he has spoilt my stomach for to-day, I shall not be able to touch a morsel for vexation—Come—oh! plague on that Pole!

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: We follow you, brother.
SP.STAGE: Exeunt V. SNARL, Mrs. ROSE, LEOPOLD, and TOTUM.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Louisa, what say you to this? Is Mr. Adelbert—

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Guilty of a baseness? Ha!—Oh, Josephine! my heart is ready to burst. (crying.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Why you seem very much interested about Mr. Adelbert, Louisa?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Who, I?—dear, no!—it's only, because—be∣cause—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Because you can't bear to see innocence suspected.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Yes, that's what I was just going to say—that's it exactly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh, nothing else to be sure. (archly)

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: No, indeed, it was nothing else. Nothing but— Heigho!—come, Josephine, we must follow the compa∣ny. Come. Hurries off with JOSEPHINE.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III. An Apartment in VAN SNARL'S House.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: LEOPOLD holding ADELBERT by the hand, and pull∣ing him forward into the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Leopold.
SP.P: NAY, nay—yet come in—this is a liberty I do not frequently take. I love the world too little to force myself upon it—but when a wrong is offered to an inno∣cent person, a very hermit may find cause to leave his cell.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I respect the justice of your sentiments, but I ought never to be seen again in this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: My brother has been in the wrong—the box is found—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Probably.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: The lining of his pocket was unsewed—and the box slipped through it—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: And from such a trifle a man's honour is to be called in question!

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: My brother is ashamed of his behaviour—he will beg your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: "Adel.
SP.P: I do not seek to witness the humiliation of another.

SP.SPEAKER: "Leop."
SP.P: He has been sharply reproved by all of us— particularly by Louisa— (observing Adelbert with at∣tention.)

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (expresses surprise—pauses—) By Louisa!— Let all be forgotten—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: The commission of my visit is then at an end.— I could wish to prolong it on my own account. Your manner has interested me—will you answer me, as a man, what I shall ask you?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: As a man!

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P:
Yes, for I would make my enquiry as a man; who, though he shut himself from the bustle of the world,
as I do, should never lock up the kind impulses of his heart towards a fellow creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I will answer you—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Your resentment of my brother's proposition was natural: but before you avowed that resentment, I fancied that I remark'd a certain embarrassment in your manner, which appeared to proceed from some other cause than indignation. What was that cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (after a pause) False shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: In what could that consist?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I am poor—very poor—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Poverty is no dishonor.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Certainly none to me. To Poland, to my struggling country, I sacrificed my wealth as I would have sacrificed my life, if it had required it—My country is no more, and we are wanderers on a burthen∣ed earth, finding no refuge but in the hearts of the hu∣mane and virtuous.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: But you are young, and industry might—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: That has ever been my friend. The little ta∣lents with which the affluence of my parents crowned my education, have preserved me from the extremes of indigence. The spirit of Poland has supplied the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Your gains then are probably small?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: When beneath the gilded roofs of the wealthy, the social banquet gladdens the heart, I take my solitary walk into the fields, and under heaven's canopy I make my poor repast. Such was my intention to-day, be∣fore your brother unexpectedly invited me to his table.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Go on.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: You know what pass'd. Had I submitted to the search proposed, my scanty meal must have been dis∣covered.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: (expressing great surprise and emotion) Young man, we must be better acquainted. Yet that cannot be without more confidence on your part.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I am a stranger—an unknown exile—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Who yet chose rather to bear the harsh suspicion that wronged you, than submit to that pity, which; however painful to you, would have exulted in your relief.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Perhaps I acted from prejudice—but let me con∣fess my pride. Had one contemptuous glance fallen on the humble pittance which I bore about me—had any one but smiled—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Had any one dared to smile, I—I would have resented it.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: You are warm, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: My heart is so. Young man, since your resi∣dence at my brother's I have marked you, and am per∣suaded of your worth—and if you will accept of a small loan from me—it will come from the hand of a friend— do not reject it.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: When I shall be unable to earn even the morsel which I concealed to-day, I will come to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Give me your hand. (they shake hands) Another time we will— (looks round in great agitation) Yonder comes Louisa—let me see you again. At another time if the recital be not painful to you, I will request your con∣fidence: and should it open afresh the wounds of your bosom, be persuaded that you will meet a friend, who will strive to heal them—one practised in sorrow—one, whose delight it would be to pour out the balm of comfort, and confer a happiness which he cannot hope himself to taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: I thought Mr. Leopold had not been gone, and I—oh! dear me, you seem quite flurried—I hope nothing has happened—I hope you have not done any thing, sir, to offend my—to offend Mr. Leopold, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Far from it, I hope—he came just now to con∣fer favors on me, which I must not accept.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: And do you mean to go, then—from—from this house, sir?— (looks down embarrassed)—Indeed, I am sorry—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Do you take an interest in my fate, Louisa?— Beware of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Beware!—and why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Because poverty, which in general silences the feelings, is not always master over the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: But the poor have hearts like other people—and when the heart is good, why should poverty silence it?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: The rich only dare to speak its language—A man like Totum dares to offer you his hand, he dares to say— I love you—

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: And what signifies his saying that? I'm sure I don't mind what he says.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: It signifies something, Louisa—for the rich man is at least received with politeness, the poor one, howe∣ver worthy in other respects, is rejected with scorn.

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: Then they who reject a worthy man, because he is poor, never deserve a rich one, I am certain.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Mr. Adelbert. I—I am come to beg your par∣don—I have found—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I beg that not a word may be spoken on the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Why may'nt I say, I found myself in the wrong? Surely 'tis not for the pleasure of saying it—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Mr. Leopold has explained all.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Oh, very well, and now I mean to make you amends.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Amends!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Ah, it goes against a man's stomach, to be sure, —but I must make you an apology—Leopold says I must, —they all say I must—It's cursed disagreeable—but I must make you amends—so you see I do it with a good grace. I'm come to tell you, that I am just sending out a ship, and you shall go supercargo.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Indeed! My gratitude robs me of words to thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: (alarmed and full of emotion) Will you go, Adelbert?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: To gain an honest livelihood! to be restored to honest industry! Oh! heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: She will sail for Africa next month.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Oh! what, will you go to Africa!

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (with surprise) for Africa!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P:
You shall not be at a farthing expence. I am determined to do the thing handsomely. I'll freight her
myself; you shall only have to purchase negroes— (Adel. shudders) What is the matter with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Humbled though I am, in poverty and in afflic∣tion; harrassed by daily cares, and wounded by hourly regrets—the bread I earn shall never force a tear from the helpless, nor bring remorse to my repast.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: So now I must not make him amends—I'm not to have my own way in any thing. What, then, you de∣spise my offer? Go on with your romantic notions:— Here's a pretty couple of you!—one does not choose a husband with eighty thousand marks, and the other won't go to sea to make his fortune for life. I wish you had nothing but sentiment and romance to eat for a fortnight, and by that time, you, Miss, would take Tilman Totum, with eighty thousand marks, and you, sir, without a pound in your pocket, would be glad to sail to the coast of Gui∣nea—Zounds! if I had not the sweetest temper in the world, I should be kept in a perpetual passion.

DIV3.STAGE: (Louisa appears agitated, and Adelbert observes her anxiously.)

SP.SPEAKER: Adel
SP.P: What agitates you, Louisa

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: You have a kind heart, Mr. Adelbert, for every one but yourself—You wo'nt go, then, to make your fortune? Oh, dear, if you had gone—Mr. Totum Would then have asked me again to marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: And would you have accepted him?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: No, never—though he were ten times as rich as he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Does my heart deceive me, or do I read yours aright, Louisa?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Were you ever in love, Louisa?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Lord! that's a strange question—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: And I have perhaps no right to ask it.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Why, though you have lived a whole year in this house, we know nothing of you, to be sure, but that you come from Poland, and that we should hardly know ei∣ther, but from your dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Would you listen with patience to my story, if I should disclose it to you, and you alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: With patience! Ah! I wish you would try.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Well,—during the last struggles of our expiring state, though private and important duties detained me at a distance, I embarked my whole fortune on the side of those, who, even against a victorious enemy, wished to defend their native country—you know the result—my situation here speaks it—except a trifling stipend that is still left to me, I have no remaining possession but health, no hope but industry—Alas! my poor country!

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: And can you be happy no where but in Poland, Mr. Adelbert?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I might yet be happy—I might—I struggle in vain against myself—Reason forgets to speak, and my heart betrays me. (he kneels to Louisa.)

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Oh, dear! you frighten me out of my wits—if any one should come—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Hope only can raise me from the ground— (Louisa hides her face with one hand, and holds out the other to Adelbert, who seizes it and presses it with rap∣ture to his lips) Then I am happy—My banishment, my wrongs, my sufferings, all—all are now a dream. Will you indeed share my poverty? Oh! then we will make it a lot the richest ones shall envy. The dawn shall light me forth to industry, and the dews of evening shall warn me from my work. Love shall season our scanty meal, and the husband, returning from his toil, shall enjoy, in contentment and affection, a kindlier rest than lights upon the downy beds of palaces.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Oh! but I am not so poor as you imagine— (Adel∣bert starts) I am not the orphan of a clergyman.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: No!

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: I have a father, and a rich one too.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Rich! then all my hopes of happiness are crushed at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: No—don't say so: I am sure, when he knows you, he must be so proud of you!

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: The poor Adelbert dared to lift his eyes to the poor Louisa. The rich Louisa is lost to him—Honor is my tyrant—I obey, against my will—but I obey. Ah! Louisa!

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Bravo, children— (both start) when lovers are caught—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (embarrassed) Do not imagine that—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: That you are in love? oh, no—it's impossible; you are a great deal too old for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I should be sorry if you thought that Louisa—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Was in love? Oh! no certainly; she is a great deal too young.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I assure you that—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: That she hates you: Is that the case, Louisa? You see she has not the heart to deny it: and you, sir, can you venture to confess?—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Who can look at Louisa without admiration?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Nay, that's a very rude speech when there's ano∣ther woman in the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: But to love her is a blissful privilege denied to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: And why so, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Because I am poor.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: And I am rich.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh, you are in the right. (to Adel) You are a good-natur'd soul, and you know what a plague it is to share a fortune with the person whom we love best, and so would save Louisa that trouble. Well, I grant you a twelvemonth for reflection; Louisa will then be nine∣teen, and you may by that time resolve to accept her with the incumbrance of her fortune. In the mean time pro∣mise me you will not take any rash step, that may make Louisa unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: You shall dispose of me. bows and exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh, then it's all very well. Make yourself easy, Louisa: the man is young, and we shall manage him.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. A Hall in Van Snarl's house.
DIV3.P: I fagg's we've got a pretty visitor to-day, sure enough. Whod'ye please to speak with, sir, says I. Any body, says he. And who be I to say, sir, that you be? Any body, says he again—Odzooks, here he is follow∣ing me.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter HANS WILLIAM, walks across the stage singing and whistling.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Be pleased to sit here awhile, sir; and I'll go on without any body, to see if any body is at home.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: So, Hans William, here you are—My father has an odd way of thinking;—I shall be more inclined to follow my own—Eh! yonder's a nice girl—I wish that may be Josephine. Enter JOSEPHINE. —Good morning, young lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: It is rather afternoon than morning.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Not where the day breaks so brightly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Very gallant, truly—May I take the liberty to ask—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Who I am? —I am a queer fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Well, but queer fellows have names.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Mine is Timothy Trifle, at your service;— "Plain Timothy with the men—dear Timothy with the women."

SP.SPEAKER: "Jos.
SP.P: With all of them?

SP.SPEAKER: "H. Wil.
SP.P: With all who wish to please me."—And now, what is your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: My—my name is Louisa Rose. I am a poor clergyman's orphan, who live in this house. Perhaps you have business with Mr. Van Snarl?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: But I have with his daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: With his daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: They say she has a great fortune; and, about six weeks ago, says my mother one evening, to me— "Dear Timothy, you are a poor fellow, and must make your fortune by marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Very wisely.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Very motherly, you mean. There's Mr. Van Snarl, says she, your father's old school-fellow, has a most charming daughter—I dare say you must know her.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh, to be sure—I know Josephine as well as I know myself.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Is she handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: When she consults her looking-glass, she shinks so.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Is she like you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: She is not handsomer than I am.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I like that—she has no need.—Has she good sense?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Not enough to prevent her from talking.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Well, I like that—Is she kind hearted, good to the poor?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh, lord! the poor get nothing in this house, if I do not give it them.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I don't like that. Is she grave or lively?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: As wild as a young devil.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Aye! Then she'll just do for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: But there's one thing, Mr. Queerfellow, with your—I like that, and I don't like that, that's against you: —Josephine's hand is promised.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: To whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: To a young man at Amsterdam—one Hans Wil∣liam.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Oh, I know him.—I'll rid her of that booby.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: What sort of a man is he?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: He? A stupid, pedantic fellow, with a full-bottom'd wig.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh, lord!

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: A shrill voice, and bandy legs.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh, lord! I don't like that.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: You don't like it? How does it concern you then?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P:
Oh, it's nothing at all to me, to be sure—only for
my friend's sake. (Aside) So I had nearly betrayed my∣sell.—Do you wish to see my father, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Your father!

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: My friend's father, I mean. (Going.)

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Hold, hold, a moment (looks stedfastly in her face.) Your name is Louisa Rose. It may be;— there's not a rose-bed in Christendom, that would re∣fuse to own you; but deuce take me if I believe you. —Shall I tell you your real name?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Well, what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Josephine.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: And what makes you suppose so?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I don't suppose—I am certain.—You disco∣vered the husband in my features at first sight, and you thought it your duty to impose upon me instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: You are a devil. Runs off.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Bravo, Hans William!—That's just the girl for you. Oh, here comes old Van Snarl, I suppose:— Egad, I'll have nothing to say to him, till I know whether that be Josephine, or not.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Your servant, Sir. (H. WILL. whistles) Here's a pretty fellow!—My daughter tells me you desire to speak with me.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Oh, that is your daughter, is she?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Why whose should she be?—Next I'm not to be father of my own children. She tells me your name is Trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: You recollect the name well enough, I sup∣pose?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Never heard it in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: When you were at school, with the old Doc∣tor with a red nose, and used to steal peaches in compa∣ny with Tom Trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Tom Trifle!—Who is he?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: My father, Sir, your poor school-fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Poor! Zounds, Sir, I do not know any thing of him. If you have nothing particular to say to me—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I have a letter to you from my father—The deuce! I have left that plaguy letter at the inn.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: There you may leave it then.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I'll run and fetch it in a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: You may break your neek by the way, if you chuse. I desire you'll never step your foot over my threshold again.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Stay, old gentleman—stay till I return with the letter—I'll make you remember Tom Trifle, depend on it.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Puppy! These young fellows, now-a-days, have no more respect for riches than they have for manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Brother, lend me the master-key of your house.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: What is it for?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I cannot tell you at present.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Then I cannot lend it you at present.—D'ye in∣tend to set all my doors wide open to-day?—First comes my daughter, "Pappa, lend me the master-key."—She is hardly gone, when you come, "Brother, lend me the master-key."—Every body wants me to lend them some∣thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Surely thou don't distrust me?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: I don't say that:—I know you won't rob me; but 'tis fair enough to refuse you for all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: On what account?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: who has got English patent locks to his doors, oh?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: For that I have a particular reason.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Who sits whole days locked up in his room, eh?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I wish to be alone.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Who has a mysterious cabinet▪ in which no mortal has dared to set foot for years together.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: That's my fancy.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, and it's my fancy not to lend you the master key. I have my particular reasons as well as you, only I'm not so unbrotherly minded; but that is no won∣der—you have not such a remarkable sweet temper as I have—There, there's the key, but take notice, if I miss a single bottle of wine, you shall be answerable for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop
SP.P:
He is in the right—but I dare not open my heart
to him. He would not understand it. Could I indeed find the bosom of a friend!

DIV3.STAGE: (LEOPOLD turns and starts at perceiving her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: I hope I don't interrupt you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Come in, Louisa, you can never be unwelcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: You are so good, and yet I am afraid you are not happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I was once happy: That's the proudest boast that mortality allows.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: And why can't you be happy again? I'm sure all good people, who know you, must wish to make you so.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Few are the hearts, Louisa, that keenly feel for the distress of others: those few the miserable cannot seek —but when once they find them—Oh! heaven!

DIV3.STAGE: lifting up his hands with great emotion.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: I am an orphan; and it signifies so little what a poor girl, like me, feels for the distress of other people, that I am afraid to tell you how many tears you have cost me.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Tears for me!

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: I am too young, to be sure, to ask you questions about yourself; but if I had a right—if I were your re∣lation, now—your daughter, or—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Would to heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Hav'nt you a daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Is she about my age?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Yes, thereabout.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: And why don't you let her live with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Dear girl, spare me! do not repeat that question.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Has she offended you?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Then you do not love her; that's a sure thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: She is my only happiness on earth!

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Then why have you banished the poor soul your presence?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: (warmly) Who says so? Those with whom she lives—and must live yet for a short time—are excellent people.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: But they are not her parents. She does not find the care of a fond mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Oh, heaven!—She has no mother!

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: That's a great pity, when she does not find a father.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Cease, girl! cease! (after a pause) Pity my sorrows

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: indeed I wish to share them. Do let me speak to you. Death has robbed you of a wife, but you have still a daughter left: she would be almost wild with joy, if she could fill her mother's place in your affection— Why will you not call her to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: She shall come.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: And, till she comes, do look on me as your daugh∣ter—let me dry your tears, and kiss the hand a daughter should kiss. Takes his hand and kisses it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Louisa, you have shaken my soul. I cannot ac∣count for the power you have over me—Yes, I will disclose to you the very sanctuary of my grief—Come to my apartment an hour hence—It is sacred to sorrow— sacred, alas! have I kept it—nor have I suffered the foot of a stranger to profane the threshold.—For one hour adieu, Louisa!—Remember—be punctual.

DIV3.STAGE: Exeunt LOUISA and LEOPOLD on opposite sides.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV. Apartment in Van Snarl's House.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. ROSE, NICOLAS, and another Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Nicolas.
SP.P: WHAT is the matter, Mrs. Rose?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: There is a crowd about them at the inn: they fought with swords, as if flesh and blood were made of wood.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Well, but who are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P:
Oh, I don't wish to know—somebody said it
was our Polish lodger—but heav'n forbid!—a couple of wild wretches—I'm certain they never read my husband's sermon on duelling—the last sermon my poor dear Dr. Olearius ever preached—

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Are they wounded?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Oh! I dare say they are both killed—they fought together, one like a cannibal, the other like a hottenpot—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Fine doings! five gashes, three side-cuts, and an eye-let hole—The Pole is a pretty fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Mr. Adelbert!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: The young gentleman wanted a bleeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: What, is Mr. Adelbert wounded?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: The point of the sword made entry by his wind-pipe, proved a running account in his ribs, and carried over into the heart— I think he's a safe man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Oh, mercy! let us go and enquire about him. Oh, that he had read my husband's last sermon on duels!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Ha!—Louisa will now be mistress Totum—Ha! no rival now—The Pole's done for, Ha! Scratch out the Pole, Ha! Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: ADELBERT'S Apartment, with an inner room and closet; and a window looking into the street—A small box standing on the table—A trunk in the corner of the room.
LOUISA opens the door, and enters timorously—then treading softly, goes towards the window and looks out.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P:
No, he is not coming; I am safe for a few min∣utes at least—poor soul! he is wounded, and perhaps he can't come home yet—he will want a great many things, which money can procure for him—so let me make haste and give him all I have. (she takes the bill of exchange
from her bosom) Now where shall I put this note, that he may see it directly? On the table—no, it won't be safe— (tries to open the box on the table) Stay, this is not lock'd —he cannot help seeing it here, when he opens the box.— (laying the paper in the box and addressing herself to it) Don't you let any body take you out, but my Adelbert, and when you come to his hands, tell him (takes up the note and kisses it) there, tell him that, Now if I can get back to my own room before any one asks for me, (goes towards the door) Oh! dear! hark I hear somebody on the stairs. "If Adelbert should have come back—No, it's impossible in this short time (listens) they are coming" —If I should be found here—cannot I hide myself?— this door is open (goes into an inner room.)

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P:
So—I might have pass'd without the master-key. It is plain the young gentleman has little to lose, or less suspicion of losing it—Well, here is a man with whom I can hold fellowship—to whom I can at last o∣pen a burthen'd heart—a comfort so long denied to me! (Louisa, overhearing, clasps her hands with expres∣sions of great affection) Spite of that noble pride which disdains to lie under an obligation, I will enjoy the plea∣sure of conferring one on him—this for a beginning (takes a roleau from his pocket) where shall I put the money?— This box—Aye it is open (opens the box and sees the note) Eh! what is this! the very bill I sent by yesterday's post to my daughter! how can it have come into this man's box?—Could the servant I sent with the letter have opened it?—he is seemingly honest—nay I know him to be so—"Fie, fie, I'm ashamed of myself when I suspect an honest man." Surely Adelbert could not (discovers suspicion and horror)— could not have re∣course to means, I shudder even to think of!—at least 'tis ground of reasonable suspicion—Shall I take back the note? —No! What right have I to take out of a stranger's chest, a paper, which I sent to Frankfort fifteen hours since!—a perfect riddle! I'll leave it where I found it (puts the note again in the box) my money too shall stay where it was— (puts the roleau in his pocket)
and now back to my solitary chamber, till some fortu∣nate conjecture shall make me once more hope that man is not altogether hateful! Exit Leopold.

DIV3.STAGE: LOUISA comes out from the inner room.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Oh, mercy! what have I done? Instead of help∣ing poor Adelbert, I have brought him into a suspicion of the basest guilt. What can I do! I must e'n go and tell my father who I am, come of it what may.
