Yes, I'll tell him all—dear, dear, I do tremble so! —let me get away before I'm caught again (goes to the door—starts and runs back again frighten'd) Oh, mercy! there's somebody else—this time perhaps it is Adelbert himself!—I feel as if I had done wrong—but heaven knows my innocent intentions; I'll hide myself once more. (retuns into the inner room.)

DIV3.STAGE: TOTUM puts his head in at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Eh! door open! now for a peep (enters) nobody here—Pole wounded—stopt at hotel—post time to debit and proceed. Now, sure as my name is Tilman Totum, I'll balance the Pole's books—"if detected, transfer ac∣count to my master, and declare I went by orders."

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: (looking out) What can Mr. Totum want, I wonder!—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (looks round the room with contempt) Light stock in warehouse—soon taken—"small compass—cre∣dit trouble and thought."—Quick—first look over papers —Eh! no desk! no books!—a fellow of no account!— Oh! may be he writes in his closet—look into back shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: (coming from the inner room) I am frighten'd out of my wits—he does not perceive me, and I'll seize this moment to make my escape—I cannot guess his de∣sign, but. whatever it may be, I'll lock the door after me, and leave him to answer for it.
SP.STAGE: Exit LOUISA, and locks the door without.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P:
(returns) Egad, he's a deep one. Where can he keep the balance sheet? must have private books somewhere— (sees the box on the table)—Oh, ho! here
we have him—now see contents—now we'll detect the spy— (takes out the bill of exchange and reads.) "On demand pay to this my order, the sum of three hundred crowns." Accepted too! As good as Bank—ah, your spies must have the wherewith (reads again) "Le—o—" What! "Leopold Van"—drawn by my master's brother! Zounds, this is forgery! "Aye, aye, this is the use he makes of getting his head into good books." We'll go over a few more folios here. (draws a chair to the table, sits down and begins to rummage the box.) If I can barely find enough to hang him, that's all, (rummaging) that's all the harm I wish him. Hark! did not I hear something? (Rises suddenly, replaces every thing in the box, except the note, and shuts the box hastily, which clo∣ses with a spring-lock.) I'll take a peep down the street, to be sure that Mr. Iron-driver is not nearer than I sus∣pect. (He runs to the window, looks out, and starts.) Oh, here's a blunder; here's a scratch—Zounds! here's Old Scratch himself. Yonder comes the Pole; I see his head. Whip off with the box—Egad, the best way.— (Takes up the box and goes towards the door.)— "We'll have a halter for you, Mr. Forgery, and then see whose is the safest head; your's with a rope round it, or Til∣man Totum's with eighty thousand marks to credit." (Goes to the door, tries to open it, and finds it locked.) Eh! how's this? the door fast!—O Lord! I am check'd. A plague on him; I hear him at the foot of the staircase— there are only thirty-four steps, two landing places, and a turning, between me and a sword through my body. Oh, the devil! here he is on the stairs. Lets return the note — (sets the box down on the table, and tries to open it.) Devil on devil! the box shuts with a spring-lock, and the lid is fast. "O lud, if this piece of forgery is found up∣on me, I shall be brought in an accomplice, and then there'll be a halter for me." I have open'd a fine head of account here. Where shall I put the note? Here is a trunk as large as our ledger. I'll insert it here; he won't think of opening this. "At least the note will be wrote off from my head."

DIV3.STAGE: (Opens the trunk, flings the note into it, and shuts it again.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Mr. Adelbert, your most obliged and obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Mr. Totum, how did you come into my room?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Brought forward per door, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I left my door lock'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Closed; pardon me, it stood open, I swear; though there's no occasion to swear that, because it is true.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: But we found it shut this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Why, yes; while I was just looking out at the window, a sudden draft came in per chimney, and closed the account—closed the door, I mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: And lock'd it too?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Lock'd it! Oh, perhaps it shuts with a spring, (aside) like some other cursed locks.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: It does not turn without a key.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: No? not turn!—then it must have been an Eddy wind,—a sort of tornado—we suffer much by them in our trade.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: And pray, Sir, what might occasion me the honour of this visit?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: O Lord, Sir, your chamber commands such a fine view of the forest! I was just taking a peep, look∣ing over your leaves—the leaves of your trees, I mean. Charming green fields, Sir! smooth as, the desks in our counting-house. What beautiful geese, Sir, on the com∣mon yonder! good quills, I warrant; eighteen stivers per dozen. You would find them excellent for book-keeping.

DIV3.STAGE: ADELBERT and HANS WILLIAM express contempt of TOTUM.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Come, you forget that you are wounded.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: A mere scratch on the wrist.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Scratches are sometimes serious things.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: A little balsam will cure it; to-morrow there will scarcely remain a scar— (goes into the inner-room.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (aside) Now is my time for getting out without loss. (to H. WIL.) I am glad to find our friend so little damaged, Sir. I wish you a good afternoon, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Stay, Sir; I could not pardon myself, if I did not declare to every one the noble assistance I have receiv∣ed from that gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Another time I shall be happy to attend—I wish you a good afternoon, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I'll tell it you in a few words.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (with great impatience) As few as you please.— I have three bills to forward to Amsterdam, seven letters of advice, thirteen dunners, all for night's post; to be ready at nine, P. M.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: As I was finishing my wine this afternoon at the Hotel, I engaged a party at Faro, which was at my side. (points to his left hand.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Yes, debtor's side.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I knew no one: a man in the dress of an offi∣cer held the bank, so, without scruple, I punted high, and lost a good round sum. On this I wanted to force the game, and put an hundred ducats on one card.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Yes, a hundred ducats; exactly that sum I shall send to agent at Leipsig to-morrow; three notes ready in iron chest, No. 21, three months date, No. 29—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Well, well, but, my friend yonder in his bed∣room, whose name I don't know, stood leaning on a chair, and observing the game.—You don't attend to me. (TO∣TUM looks frequently to the door of the bed-room.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Yes—I do—Sir; attention is the best point of business—I am attending, Sir—to— (aside) see how I can get off before I am caught by the Pole again.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: The card turn'd against me, and I was pushing the cash to the bank; stop, Sir, cried he, take your mo∣ney back; you are cheated. (TOT. draws back, H. WIL. follows.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Yes—cheated.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Up jumps the bank-holder, insults my friend; both drew their swords, and before we could part them, both were wounded.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Double entry—good check—very extraordinary indeed. I wish you a good afternoon, sir. (Adelbert re∣turns from the inner room, and advances. Totum going out, meets him) A plague! Here is the Pole again.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (holding his wrist with the other hand) There, it is dress'd. Mr. Totum, be so good to lift the lid of that trunk, and take out a ribbon which lies at the top.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Sir! take out!—excuse me, sir, I never take any thing out of other people's trunks.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: You see my hands are engaged. If you will be so obliging to tie the ribbon, which you will find there, round my wrist, by to-morrow the whole story will be forgotten.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I shall never forget it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (opening the trunk, and taking out the ribbon, which he ties hastily on Adelbert's wrist) Well, if I must I—but you had better close the trunk again, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (looks into the trunk and takes out the bill of ex∣change) What's this? a bill of exchange!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: A bill of exchange!

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Where did this come from?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (aside) As if he did not know where it came from —Oh! no doubt, arrived per mail—post to credit—goods delivered.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: How came it into my trunk?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Oh, every body knows that.—When received, wrote on to cash, and then put under lid.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I'm all amazement! (a moment's pause) Mr. To∣tum, this must be your deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Mine, sir! You don't believe, sir, that I—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: It is hard to believe, indeed; but all circum∣stances considered—This gentleman shall judge. When I went out this morning, I left nothing but a few trifles of apparel in my trunk, and at my return I find you locked in my room, and here a note of exchange. It is in vain to deny it; you must have put it into my trunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Well, sir—if I must confess, I did put it into the trunk, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Generous man! how have I mistaken you!— You saw me cast down by misfortune, and wished to lift me from the ground. But this, sir, cannot be accepted.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Zounds! it is accepted already. You have only to offer it for payment, and then— (aside) we'll have you taken up for forgery, and lift you from the ground presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Mr. Totum, I must insist on your taking it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Take it! I would not take it at discount.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Can you refuse to take back three hundred crowns?

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Certainly one would be very glad to take three hundred crowns—but—but—

SP.SPEAKER: "Adel.
SP.P: It is your property." You owned you put it into my trunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Yes—but I swear I found it in your box.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: That is impossible. I have not so much wealth in the world. If it do not come from you—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: From me! I protest before this gentleman, I have nothing to do with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Then I must entreat you, at least, to carry it back to the person from whom it came.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: (aside) That person is the devil.—I beg to be ex∣cused, Sir. I don't keep cash there. I don't know the parties.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Sir, I insist on it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: I cannot, indeed Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: You offend me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: I am sorry for it Sir; but—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I beg—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: I can by no means—I—I— (sees the door open) I wish you a good afternoon, Sir. I see the door's open, and so—egad, here's a bolt for it. (runs out.)

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Do you really think such a fellow as that ca∣pable of an act of generosity?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: No—but the generous Leopold—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Be who he may, has chosen a vile deputy. But let that pass—one thing is clear—from what I have now witness'd—you are possessed of every thing that a brave man should have, except money. My purse is at your command—you have open'd my heart already; and I should think myself a mean wretch indeed, if, when the strings of my heart are touch'd, those of my purse did not instantly follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: The debt that lies on your heart, pay in the heart's coin, when you please. At present I am in no want of money.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I heartily wish you were for my own sake. Do you know you have brought me into a house where I am no stranger?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: As a merchant, the house of Van Snarl cannot be unknown to you.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: That's not all: I have a close speculation here on the person of one Louisa Rose.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (starts) Louisa Rose!

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Do you know her?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (embarrassed, but recollecting himself) Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: You do! then there is really such a person?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: There is only one Louisa Rose in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I comprehend—Hans William, you are come here a day too late. Is she rich?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Unfortunately she is.

SP.SPEAKER: Hans Wil.
SP.P: Unfortunately! for whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: What have I said! pardon me, my friend. You have an honest open countenance, and it led me half way to a confession, which—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: You may very safely entrust to me—Go on.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: A confidence so rashly ventured—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Is, I own, as rare as the generous action, by which you have made me your friend for life.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I cannot resist you—yes, I love Louisa—the a∣gitation in which you see me, will tell you how much I love her. While I believed her the orphan of a poor and humble clergyman, I flattered myself I might have ob∣tained her—but, alas!—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: What! did not Von Snarl acknowledge her for his daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Louisa his daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: He told me so himself just now—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: She said her father was rich! (with emotion.)

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I am to marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: (starts) You are to marry her!

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I came hither for no other purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: And will you marry her?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: (holds out his hand to ADELBERT) What! and break the heart of a man who has risked his life for me! give me your hand. (they shake hands) If you can∣not make an answer for me to that question, I'll make none for myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: But I heard of a match that was in treaty for Jo∣sephine.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Josephine! well, that's she, is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Von Snarl has but one daughter, has he?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Did not you say Louisa too was his daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Eh!—I begin to suspect some mistake—let us examine, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: You came to this house to marry Louisa—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: No: I came to marry Josephine, Von Snarl's daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: And who wants to force Louisa on you?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Why, are not Josephine and Louisa the same person?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: By no means.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Then one of them has made a fool of me. Which of the two is the merrier?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Josephine.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Hurra! that's my girl then!—shake hands a∣gain—the first was a sentimental shake, and this is a mer∣ry one. We shall not be rivals.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Again I do not comprehend you.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Why, the truth is, I am very properly served —I came into this house under a false name, and the girls have outwitted me—Josephine suspected my design, and pass'd herself on me for Louisa Rose. I'll be reveng'd; tho' egad, I like her better than ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Then you know nothing of Louisa?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I never imagined, till this moment, that there was such a person in existence. I'll go down and look for that merry girl again, and if I find her— (going.) One word before I go, my dear new friend—You perceive I am likely to have some interest in this house, and if it can avail you with Louisa, you shall find that the mark a ras∣cal has left on your wrist, will be much sooner worn away than the impression you have made on an honest man's heart. Come along.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. A Hall in Van Snarl's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. ROSE, with keys in her hand, JOSEPHINE following.

SP.SPEAKER: Josephine.
SP.P: MRS. Rose!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R
SP.P: Aye, to be sure! Mrs. Rose must be every where at once! Well, child, what do you want with Mrs. Rose?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I thought I saw Mr. Adelbert return.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Yes, yes, he has come home sure enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: And a young gentleman with him—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: A young gentleman! —I was on the stair-case, with a sugar-loaf under my arm—so I stopp'd and made a curtsy. Mr. Adelbert bow'd very politely, I must say that for him—but the other young gentleman brush'd by me, as if he would have knock'd me down.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: He was attentive only to his friend, who was wounded.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Manners are good at all times, say I.
Well, Louisa—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Have you heard what occasioned the duel?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Oh! it was such a generous action of Mr. Adelbert, to—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: A generous action! to thrust a sword through a man's body! You have forgot, I fancy, what excellent things my husband said in his sermon against duels— Poor dear Mr. Olearius!

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Dear mother, if you would now but step up to poor Mr. Adelbert—perhaps he wants help—you have several fine receipts for wounds, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Child, I have a great many excellent wound balsams—but I step up into the young man's room!— You know before one has come to a certain age—

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: A certain age!—and what does that signify? I think at any time of life we should give our help to a fel∣low creature, when it is wanted.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: You are right, my dear—When we can be useful, we must sometimes disregard slanderous tongues; —so I'll carry Mr. Adelbert the black ointment, which stands on the chimney in my room—but don't let any body know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: There's only that young man there—he won't tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Oh, mercy! if it should be known that I visited a young man in his bed-room!—however, I'll carry him the black ointment. Exit Mrs. Rose.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Now, my dear Josephine, let me tell you what has pass'd—but I am so confused, I can hardly speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: For joy or grief?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Oh! for both. In the first place,—my father—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Whose whims begin to tire me—

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: I summoned up all my courage, and spoke to him—and am so happy—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Well—what has pass'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: He promis'd to tell me all his sorrows,

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Then I don't wonder at your being so happy.— Upon my word you are much obliged to him—

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: And he desired me to meet him in his room—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: And are you prepared in what you will say to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: No, not I—but my heart will be full—and then I warrant I shan't want words to tell it's meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: (without) Josephine! Josephine!

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Who calls me?

DIV3.STAGE: [Louisa goes to the side of the stage, Hans Willian enters and seizes her hand.]

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Oh! are you found by your true name? eh! who is this? I beg a thousand pardons, ma'm—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Ha! ha! fairly caught! Give me leave sir, to introduce you to this young lady. This is miss Joseph∣ine—My dear Josephine, this is Mr. Timothy Trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Sir, my name is Louisa Rose—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Another Louisa Rose? and yet I heard a per∣son in this house, say just now, that there is but one Lou∣isa Rose in the world— (Josephine smiles, Louisa blush∣es) Well, my dear Louisa Roses, inform me where I may find the real genuine Josephine?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: What is your pleasure, sir, with her?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Exactly this—if you are both Louisa Rose, I have no business with either of you—but if you are both Josephine, I'm resolved I'll marry you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Is not this the gentleman you expected to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: What, my lover, Hans William? Oh, no, he wears a full bottom'd wig, has a shrill voice, and is bandy-legg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: He is very like me, for all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: No. I have been expecting him this whole morn∣ing, and in the mean time comes this saucy—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Take care what you are going to call me—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Stay, Louisa, don't go—not that I'm afraid of be∣ing left alone with Mr. Trifle, but that—

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: I must go now, to the person I told you of— when I come back, I'll meet you in your room exit Loui.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: And now, sir, I desire to know whether you are Hans William or Trifle?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Which do you wish?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Neither—Can you speak the truth?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Do it then this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I am in love with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Who ask'd you that?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Have you settled, what day will be convenient for our wedding?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: What, then, you are determined to marry me?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Positively.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: And have you spoken to my father?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: And what said he?

SP.SPEAKER: H. W.
SP.P: He requested me never to put my foot over his threshold again.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Indeed! and what induces you to refuse him such a trifling request?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I do not—I mean to take him at his word, only I design to take you with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Are you quite sure of that?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Quite—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P:
Without letting me know who you are! When
a man intends to rob an honest girl of her name, he should at least provide her with another.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Why, I gave you your choice of two.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Well, then, your name is not Trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: No more than yours is Louisa Rose.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Why did you wish to impose on me?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I'll tell you. Your father and mine have treated our love a little too much in a mercantile manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Our love!

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I did not wish to contradict my father, and as my heart was free, I neither promised or refused, but I was determined first to take a look at you. If I had not liked you, I should have been off again in a moment: but—here I am still—and, to own the truth at once—I do like you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: You're very flattering.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: And therefore meaning to be a dutiful son—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Hold, hold, not in such haste—perhaps I may have a mind first to look at you too.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: With all my heart— (turns round)

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: The outside is well enough—but who will answer for the inside?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: That you'll find out after the wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: A clear bargain, my father says, prevents quar∣rels—suppose we agree to tell our own faults to one another, and then try if we can be friends.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Well, do you begin.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: First, I am hotheaded and passionate.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: That may be cured by good temper on my part.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I'm careless—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: That will be cured when you have a wife to look after.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I am vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: That you must only be of me.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I shall be vainer than ever, if I win you for my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Well, that I'll forgive—proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: That is all.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh, then you may be endur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I hope so—and now it's your turn to tell your faults.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I have none.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: None at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Girls have no faults before marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: And after marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Have none but in the eyes of their husbands.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: So we have settled our accounts already?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Hold! hold! there are a few other things to be discussed. Have you no bad habits?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: None that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: How do you pass the day when you are at home?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I have a foolish custom of my country—I like a pipe for an hour or two—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I cannot endure it—you must give up the pipe,

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I shall find that difficult, perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: As you please—I can play with my lap-dog while you are smoking.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Your lap-dog!

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I can leave him when you leave your pipe.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I give up the pipe—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I give up the lap-dog; well, proceed with the day.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil·
SP.P: I love to dine at two.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I hate to dine 'till four.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: For your sake I can dine an hour later.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: To oblige you, I would dine an hour earlier.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Then at three—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Agreed.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: After dinner I take a nap.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos,
SP.P: And I take an airing.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Without me?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I cannot take your bed in my carriage.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: But suppose I don't sleep—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Then I don't go out.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: In the evening I go to the club.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: And I invite company.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Whom I don't know!

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I cannot ask your club into my apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Then I shall stay at home—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: And I shall have no company but those whom you invite.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Well—so far we proceed cordially—but I have one bad habit, I own, not so easy to be got rid of— you will overlook it, I dare say—I cannot help falling in love with every pretty woman I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Oh, that's of no importance at all.

SP.SPEAKER: H. W.
SP.P: Indeed!—well, that's very good natured. nettled

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I cannot be otherwise than good-natured on that head, because I have exactly the same fault.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Eh!

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I cannot help liking every handsome man that comes in my way.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: I like to hear men pay me compliments

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil
SP.P: Do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Swear solemn vows to me—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: To be sure—what is the matter with you?— You dislike it, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Suppose we both leave off this last trick?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: How is that to be managed?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Suppose I have no eyes but for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: To that I consent.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Suppose you have none but for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: That will be the consequence of the other.

SP.SPEAKER: H Wil.
SP.P: Say you so? then give me your hand in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: Yes—but you must first obtain my father's leave to step over the threshold.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: (snatches her hand and kisses it) Come along my charming girl, I'll obtain your father's leave, to do every thing that you bid me, as long as we live.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: [LEOPOLD'S Apartment, hung round with black; at the back of the stage the door of a Cabinet, or small inner room, closed, and silk curtains drawn before it. Fur∣niture suited to the melancholy of the apartment.]
DIV3.P:
An hour has nearly passed, and Louisa will presently be here. For the first time, since fifteen years have elap∣sed,
the foot of a stranger will tread this sancturay of my sorrows—for the first time my heart will open itself to sympathy, and the tears of another being will be mixed with mine. I feel myself unaccountably attracted to∣wards that good girl. Hark! she is come.
DIV3.STAGE: LOUISA opens the door, and enters timorously.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: You are true to your appointment, Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: I have counted the minutes ever since I left you. What a dark and dismal room this is!

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: It wears the colour of mourning—In the first hours of grief, the eye feeds with pleasure on these congenial hues—but a real and lasting grief outlives the very sense of these vain distinctions—In my sight these walls are now a mere blank—So also to me is life— mournful and void.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: You said your life was not always so sad.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I enjoyed its morning—but its noon was stormy— and now, its closing eve, shade deepening over shade, wraps me bewildered and perplexed, in cheerless darkness.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: But indeed, indeed, I am sure your evening may be brighter if you choose.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: If I choose;—Can I command the clouds that lower round my setting sun?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Yes, I do think you may. Now, pray, listen to me;—You have been very good to me—you have given me your confidence—you have made me feel as if I be∣longed to you—and now you have done all this—don't be angry with me, if I speak what I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Be angry with you, my good girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Yes—don't be angry with me, if I tell you, that I think you have been unkind to yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: How so, Louisa?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: By casting one from you, whose love and duty teach her, that her chief happiness would be to give you comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I understand you, Louisa. But tell me—tell me, girl, wherefore you are so warmly interested in my daugh∣ter's fate—You spoke to me of her before.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: She—she is my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Why did you not inform me of this sooner?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Because I know how earnestly your poor child sighs for her father's love—because I could find no rea∣son why you should be so severe towards her—and because I wanted to observe you first, and learn on what account it was you hated her.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Hated her! tell me something of my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: I can tell you nothing, but of her unhappiness —of her tears.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: (affected) Does she feel such love for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Does she love you!—Oh!—Since she has been old enough to learn what happiness means, the wish to be known to you, has been the dearest of her heart. Her tears have often fallen upon my bosom. She has, many and many a time, felt bitter anguish, while she sat alone sighing out—"My father does not love me!"

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: She shall return to me—

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Shall she?—shall she indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Yes! Let her come! And when clasping her in my arms, joy, shall overpower my senses, and tears shall be my only utterance, then—then she shall be assured that I love her.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: (trembling, and grasping Leopold's hand) I—I hope I may believe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: You have a right to doubt; but do not condemn me, girl, if I have appeared cold and unconcerned for one, whose welfare is so dear to me—such, as, for these few months past, you have seen me—such have I been for seventeen years; during that period, I have sometimes lived for men, but no one has lived for me. You, my good girl, are the first who have rekindled in my heart the desire to see my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Then blessed be the moment in which I entered this house!

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P:
I bless it.—Hear me, Louisa, censure me, but pity and excuse me. I was once rich, for I possessed in a virtuous wife, the only true riches in this world, Con∣tent and Cheerfulness. When the Creator finished his glorious work of nature, he added its last bright ornament, Woman! I loved one alone, among all beings:—I had chosen her from a world, and from a world I would still choose her. The years of our first love fell swiftly into that eternity where she now resides. The birth of a
daughter was the dearest and last moment of my happi∣ness. Scarcely had she beheld the light▪ when her mo∣ther died— (Louisa appears affected) her infant cries were the dirge of all my joys on earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Poor innocent!

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: While yet Emilia's grave was fresh, I clasp'd her infant to my bosom, and flying from the world, re∣solved to live for my child alone—She was the only treasure left to me on earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: And why did you forsake that child?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Mark me—As I convey'd my little one to the fostering refuge I had provided for her, methought her mother's spirit beamed in her features—Oh! what did that look effect! The keen remembrance of my loss, pierced anew into my soul—I dreaded to turn again to∣wards my child—her existence had destroyed what was dearer to me than my own—I entrusted her with those, of whose kind hearts I was well assured—Business call∣ed me away—concerns of my wife's fortune— (after a pause, he shudders) I have never returned to my child.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Had she deserved this?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Day after day, year after year, have I ardently sighed to meet my child again. But she is well and hap∣py—and what could my presence bestow? The sight of my affliction—of my misery—I strove to rouse me from despair—I turned from the grave, which had devoured my hopes, and sought for consolation among men—I told them my sorrows, and met derision—until at last I shut my bosom against the world, and fled, where only I could escape torment—to solitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Ah! I'm afraid you found little comfort there.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P:
Such as you see me now possess. But here has fan∣cy furnished me with ample food for sadness—here have I framed a sacred record of my beloved Emilia—here I gathered every remember'd object, that had been dear to her—yes—here her spirit dwells; here often in my thoughts has communed with me—Else, how could I have endured so much? [During these last lines, LEOPOLD takes LOUISA's hand with great emotion, and leads her towards the door of the cabinet—stops suddenly.) Wilt thou not tremble, girl? Yet, 'tis imagination fills
the scene—all is but shew—the mockery of my heart's pangs.—

DIV3.STAGE: (Opens the folding doors of the cabinet, and discovers, within, an emblematic transparency, in which is the name of EMILIA, written in large characters.)

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: (nearly fainting, falls on the ground) My mother!

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: What do you mean?—who art thou Louisa?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Your daughter. (Leopold, trembling, raises her) Forgive me, my dear father, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Art thou indeed my daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: Oh! does not your heart tell you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Oh, yes—thou art—thou art my child.

SP.SPEAKER: Loui.
SP.P: My letters could not move you—I wish'd still to try if I could gain your love—Josephine assist∣ed me—I pass'd here for the daughter of—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: I comprehend it all—How could I so long deny myself this comfort! (embraces her) Support me, my child—lead me nearer—that, in the presence of my mother's spirit, I may bless thee—

DIV3.STAGE: (A noise heard without. Leopold starts, and shuts the cabinet. Adelbert enters hastily.)

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Pardon, generous man—pardon this intrusion— I must have leave to speak—you have given me so singu∣lar a proof of your benevolence.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: You surprize me—I, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Was it not by your order that this note was con∣veyed into my room?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: No, not by mine,— (looks at LOUISA, who casts down her eyes) but I guess by whom it was bestow'd. That glowing cheek, that down-cast look disclose the truth—the person, to whom you are indebted, stands be∣fore you—

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: Louisa!—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Give me the note—Come, my children, let us hasten to meet my brother—he has long borne with my discontent—he shall be the first witness of my returning joy. Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. The Hall.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter TOTUM, in a great bustle, and NICOLAS.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Well, Nicolas—are the constables posted?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: They are ready, down at the door—

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Down at the door—right. Let no one take his head out of the house; if I call, be ready, at a moment's notice—away—no blunders—good Nicolas.

DIV3.STAGE: Exeunt TOTUM and NICOLAS on opposite sides.
Enter VON SNARL, JOSEPHINE, and HANS WIL∣LIAM.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Fine doings, indeed! Did not I tell you never to come into my house again?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: And did not I tell you that I would come in∣to it again? This is the letter from my father—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Psha! I suppose it's all about the red nose and the peaches.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Read it.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: What should I read it for? I have told you al∣ready to get out of my house.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: I'll, go, as soon as you have read the letter.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, you shall not spoil the sweetness of my temper. I have read many useless letters in my life be∣fore this: (opens the letter and reads) "The bearer of this, my lawful son and heir, Hans William, (surprised) whom I send in good condition"—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Yes, I'm in pretty good case—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: "By this day's mail"—hem—"Vander Hou∣sen & Co."—the devil! you have taken me in, (forces a laugh) ha—ha—I thought you had too honest a face for a cheat. Did not I tell you, Josephine, he was of prime quality—but Hans must not come near you— (to H. W.) give me your hand—you are a rogue and a wit; but if you had not been a rich rogue, like myself—

SP.SPEAKER: Jos.
SP.P: (to H. WIL.) You would be a rogue and a thief—

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: And must never more have put my foot over the threshold—

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Well, well, why d'ye put me in mind of that? If I had not the sweetest temper—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Brother, give me joy—Louisa Rose shall be married to-day, as you said.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Oh, she consents at last to take eighty thousand marks, does she?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: She shall give her hand, as it should always be given, where the heart guides it.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: And why did she plague me this morning with all that nonsense?—Only to put me in a passion!

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: Now, Sir, the constables are at the door—he can∣not have negociated the bill already—Oh, yonder he comes—now, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: (looks towards the side scene) Adelbert! a bill! what is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Why, what should it be? Totum has a charge against my lodger for a note, purporting to be drawn by you, for three hundred crowns.

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Against my friend!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: Your friend! Do you know any thing more of him?

SP.SPEAKER: H. Wil.
SP.P: Yes, I know him for one who thinks every stranger entitled to his regard, and who will rather risk his life, than suffer an honest man to become the dupe of a knave. Perhaps I may find (looks at TOTUM with scorn) an opportunity of doing as much for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: Here is the note, written by myself—you found it in the hands of a man of integrity, and, as a proof of my esteem for him, I mean to make him heir to my whole fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: You do!—and pray what becomes of your daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P:
Behold her. (VON SNARL and TOTUM ex∣press surprise.) In the fond and artless affections of her
mind, while I recognized the image of her whom I ado∣red, I read likewise, in forcible characters, my own duty —yes—this is my daughter, and, if I guess the heart a∣right—this is my son.

SP.SPEAKER: Adel.
SP.P: An outcast!

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: You have found an asylum here. Accept her, Adelbert: with my whole heart I give her to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: Oh, what a fine sermon my poor dear Dr. Olearius wou'd have made on this occasion!

SP.SPEAKER: V. Sn.
SP.P: So! I shall give Louisa a wedding-dinner, as I said—I'm right this time, in spite of you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Tot.
SP.P: And if this be the case, I may as well make the constables void.—Hymen has protested my draught: and, for fear the Pole should make a scratch in my ledg∣er, I won't leave him a single side for a memorandum sheet.—Hang Hymen!—Plague light on the Pole!

SP.SPEAKER: Leop.
SP.P: The indulgence of a gloomy temper has stolen from my life its sweetest hours, and drawn sighs from the bosom of innocence—my child, forgive me!—Amid tears of anguish and despair you were baptised.—Amid those of repentance and joy, receive a father's blessing!—"Con∣vinced of my error, I will now return with cheerfulness to the world, and bear, without repining, the lot which heaven has assigned me.—The present emotions of my heart instruct me, that there is no cordial for a parent's sorrows beyond the virtuous affection of A DAUGHTER."
